Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support - 26th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT 2017)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 26th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques is the premier forum for presenting, discussing, and debating innovative compiler and architectural techniques for advanced computing and communication systems. This conference brings together researchers in fields related to architecture, compiler, application, language and systems for technical exchange on traditional system topics and emerging research areas. The PACT community has enjoyed a close interaction between academic researchers and industrial designers and aims to continue this tradition at PACT 2017. This project funds student travel grant, and includes a goal to broaden and diversify the student participation in the 26th International Conference on Parallel Architecture and Compilation Techniques (PACT 2017). This year's conference, being in its 26th year, will be held from September 9-13, 2017 in Portland, Oregon, USA.

This proposal has two primary Broader Impacts. First, the students receiving travel support will benefit from the opportunity to engage in the technical, professional, educational and social exchanges that PACT fosters. The conference serves as an open forum to exchange research results and develop new ideas, as an educational platform to expose students to new research methodologies, tools, and infrastructures, and as a social event to network and prepare students as future researchers. Second, the PACT conference will be indirectly strengthened. More tutorials and workshops can be associated with the main conference, as a result of increased number of student attendance that this travel grant will enable. More broadly, this travel support will increase the attendance of under-represented minorities and talented undergraduate students, attracting them to graduate schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Student Travel Support–26th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT 2017)

Carole­Jean Wu, Arizona State University, Student Travel Chair for PACT 2017

Overview:

The 26th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques is the premier forum for presenting, discussing, and debating innovative compiler and architectural techniques for advanced computing and communication systems. This conference brings together researchers in fields related to architecture, compiler, application, language and systems for technical exchange on traditional system topics and emerging research areas. The PACT community has enjoyed a close interaction between academic researchers and industrial designers and we continue this tradition at PACT 2017.

Intellectual Merit:

The purpose of this proposal is to provide support to broaden and diversify the student participation in the 26th International Conference on Parallel Architecture and Compilation Techniques (PACT 2017). PACT is the premier event that brings together researchers from architecture, compilers, applications and languages to present and discuss innovative research of common interest. This year’s conference, being in its 26th year, was held from September 9-13, 2017 in Portland, Oregon, USA.

Broader Impacts:

This proposal has two primary merits. First, the students receiving travel support benefited from the opportunity to engage in the technical, professional, educational and social exchanges that PACT fosters. The conference serves as an open forum to exchange research results and develop new ideas, as an educational platform to expose students to new research methodologies, tools, and infrastructures, and as a social event to network and prepare students as future researchers. Second, the PACT conference was indirectly strengthened. Tutorials and workshops were associated with the main conference, as a result of increased number of student attendance that this travel grant enabled. More broadly, this travel support increased the attendance of under-represented minorities.

Outcome:

Student travel applications were solicited via the conference website and the email lists of professional organizations. This year, there were 140 registered attendees, and a total of 29 (out of 58) students applied for the travel award. All 19 student applicants from US-based institutes received travel awards. 

The tables below show the final list of award recipients, their universities, the amounts awarded, and demography information. The award selections were prioritized as follows:

Students from universities that do not have a strong tradition in the PACT research domain; US students or universities;
attendees who belong to under­represented minorities (including women); conference or workshop paper presenters; 

The award amounts from NSF were determined as follows:

There were six main conference presenters receiving the student travel award; each of whom received $1,100. There was one main conference paper author who did not present the paper but attended the conference, receiving $600. There were four workshop paper presenters receiving the student travel award; each of whom received $660. There were six student poster presenters; each of whom received $660. Finally, there were two students attending the conference, who received $600. Most of the students received an award amount that fully covered the incurred expense. 

No students from institutes outside the US were funded.

 


Last Modified: 11/16/2017
Modified by: Carole-Jean Wu
